error: Error: Invalid option selected. Press enter to go back.
gameover: Game over. Press enter to terminate the program.

warnings: Please ensure that all of the following words are easily readable. Adjust your color settings if they are not.
title.prompt: Please enter the number corresponding to your choice to proceed:

text1: I feel empty like the blank canvas standing before me[1;37;40m
text2: [1;34;40m Whenever I feel empty I like to dream
Deep in my dreams there is someone who can help
The road will be long and tiring
But the day is young and so am I[1;37;40m
intro.question: [1;34;40m Where shall I begin my journey?[1;37;40m
choices: Please enter the number corresponding to your choice to proceed:

fight.win:
[1;34;40m I have proven myself worthy, and may now add a sketch of this creature to my collection.[1;37;40m

 [1;33;40m{}[1;37;40m has been added to your discard pile.
fight.abandon:
[1;34;40m
 Perhaps not all things are meant to be painted. Surely, some of my sketches must be flawed.[1;37;40m
fight.forget_cards:
[1;34;40m
 Using my lost life essence, I shall burn away some of these worthless scribbles.[1;37;40m
death: [1;34;40m My mind is pained with the struggle of creativity
I keep looking for something new to paint, but nothing comes to mind
Perhaps this dream was all for naught
Perhaps I was never meant to be an artist
It is now time to wake up
With an empty canvas standing before me
reshuffle: [1;34;40m I have turned the final page of my sketchbook
Now is a good opportunity to add the new drawings I have learned
In the last few steps of my journey
But in the murky depths of my soul
Something which I have been struggling to conceal
And finds its way into my sketchbook

intro: I find myself in the clearing of a forest
Surrounded by the warm colors of fall
A path before me stretches to a great monastery in the distance
Many statues watch over the road with great patience
That the inhabitants of this peculiar place are ready to test my skill and wit
Then perhaps they shall grant me insight on where to go next.[1;37;40m
first_battle: [1;34;40m As my first steps scatter the red leaves across the soil
I find myself inspired by the statues surrounding the trail
Surely they would not mind appearing in a painting or two
interlude1: [1;34;40m I continue my path towards the monastery
Breathing calmly the fresh air of the forest
Perhaps I should enjoy this moment of peace
And paint a few more statues along the way.[1;37;40m
boss1: I have travelled down the path of statues
And I now find myself at the gates of the monastery
But just as I prepare to open the doors and see what lies inside
I feel a hand lay down on my right shoulder
"Not yet, Disciple. You have one more test to pass."
boss2: [1;34;40mI turn around and see a man draped in bright red clothing, decorated with the images of a variety of animals
I recognize every single one of them as one of the statues I have encountered in this eventful beginning of my journey
In fact, all of them but one
Before I can get a closer look at it, the Master bows and blocks my view of the unfamiliar figure
"You have stayed in our humble grove for so little time"
"And yet you have learned so much"
"It is now time to put all the knowledge you have acquired to the test"
"And face me, the Master of the Autumn Monastery, Sculptor of Statues."

text1: [1;34;40mThe Master turns the handle of his Monastery and invites me inside
I take a moment to admire my surroundings, decorated by golden mosaics of the grove's inhabitants
A small square red mat lies at the center of the room, surrounded by four bonsai trees
I suddenly remind myself of the mysterious figure on the Master's robes
But before I can get a closer look at it, the Master bows and blocks my view of the unfamiliar silhouette yet again
"Breathe deeply, for you are no longer my disciple."
honor0: "It saddens me greatly to say it, but your journey ends here."
"Farewell, Artist. Perhaps your next attempt shall be more successful?
Before I can express my disagreement, I feel the world around me fades into nothingness
When my vision returns, I find myself sitting still
With an empty canvas standing before me
honor1: "As you have shown to be not completely talentless, I must allow you to pursue your travels."
"Know this: you must seek to improve your skills, for the creatures you will encounter beyond my domain are not as merciful as I am."
"For now, Artist, sit on the red mat, close your eyes, and dream vividly of your next destination."
honor2: "You have learned well, and your sketchbook is filled with skillful drawings."
"Look inside it; I have added one of mine as a way for you to remember my teachings."
"I regret to inform you that we must now part ways."
"I can gurarantee that all you have learned in my grove will be of great use to you."
"And now, Artist, sit on the red mat, close your eyes, and dream vividly of your next destination."
honor3: [1;34;40mThe Master pauses, then whispers, "the new Master."
"You have outdone me in every way possible."
"I have added a creation of mine in your sketchbook, but I imagine it pales in comparison of what you have acquired so far."
"Listen. I must tell you something important."
"From all the statues you have seen in my grove, one is missing."
"That statue is the Lamb; a frail and weak creature, which felt completely out of place among the talented residents of my domain."
"I tried many times to make her better, but to no avail"
"One morning, she left my grove, never to be seen again"
"If you see her, wherever you will go..."
"Tell her the Autumn Monastery is always ready to welcome her back"
"And I could say the same thing for you, dear Master"
"Now, I shall not retain you any longer. Please sit on the red mat, close your eyes, and dream vividly of your next destination."
text2: I find myself in the middle of a great staircase, floating in the void
Hearing a faint buzzing sound from the summit, I turn my attention towards it
A richly decorated gate coated in thick, sweet and golden honey urges me to approach it
And perhaps taste some of its delightful nectar along the way
A sudden orchestral crescendo coming from the bottom of the stairway snaps me out of my reverie
An entrance made of soft purple cloth to what seems to be a circus invites me inside
And shall perhaps allow me to take part in the show taking place behind it
Where shall I pursue my travels?

observatory: I find myself at the base of a great tower
Surrounded by the echoing humming of the cosmos
At the very summit of the spire
A telescope which shall grant priceless insights
On the astral secrets of the universe
Then perhaps I may use it and plan where to go next.[1;37;40m
hive(not used): I find myself in the middle of a bustling city
Surrounded by the deafening buzzes of many insect-like humanoids
Flies, moths, butterflies, bees and many others alike
March, flutter and crawl towards a great palace built atop the walls of the metropolis
The humming songs chanted by the ruler of the capital
Then perhaps I may ask the Queen for advice on where to go next

tiger: I stand before the statue of a ferocious striped beast
Whose savagery would no doubt be a great addition to my sketchbook
I can hear its callous, uncaring voice
"Perhaps your remains will be tastier than the last"
"This grove shall be the last thing you see."
swan: I stand before the statue of a magnificent white bird
Whose silhouette would no doubt be a great addition to my sketchbook
I can hear its beautiful signing voice
"My power is unmatched and my beauty without equal"
"You appear to be a rather talented Artist"
"Therefore I shall allow you to paint my magnificence without hardships"
dragon: I stand before the statue of a formidable red dragon
Whose power would no doubt be a great addition to my sketchbook
I can hear its booming, majestic voice
"I see you have chosen the path of the Monastery"
"Know that I am the ruler of this grove"
"And that only my Master, who resides inside the monastery, can surpass my prowess"
"Can you, human? Show me what you are capable of."
crane: I stand before the statue of a silent, sleeping crane
Whose placidity would no doubt be a great addition to my sketchbook
Despite all my attempts to wake it, as I imagine that their beauty would increase tenfold once awoken
As I nervously unpack my painting tools
I worry that the crane may be dreaming of me, and of what perils I may encounter on my journey.
leopard: I stand before the statue of a swift spotted feline
Whose alacrity would no doubt be a great addition to my sketchbook
I can hear its growling, threatening voice
"I will chase, and you shall run"
"If they do, I will allow you to paint me, and perhaps learn that speed over carefulness is sometimes your best bet."
snake: I stand before the statue of a slithering, scaly snake
Whose elusiveness would no doubt be a great addition to my sketchbook
I can hear its hissing, rattling voice
"Ssso, human, you have chosen me as the sssubject of your next creation?"
"Please, take a ssseat, and don't forget a single detail of my glissstening ssscalesss."
monkey: I stand before the statue of a joyful, smiling monkey
Whose mischief would no doubt be a great addition to my sketchbook
As I prepare my painting tools, I notice one of the pages bearing one of my previous creations has vanished
I can hear its playful, high-pitched voice
"Surely I am beautiful enough to replace it. Go on, paint me, Artist."
stag: I stand before the statue of a noble, venerable stag
Whose stature would no doubt be a great addition to my sketchbook
I can hear its deep, respectful voice
"Disciple of the Master, you walk among our garden"
"Be respectful of all those who have come before you"
"As each of your steps flatten the soil of our great Monastery."
mantis: I stand before the calming statue of a praying mantis
Whose serenity would no doubt be a great addition to my sketchbook
I can hear its tranquil whispers
"Through anger lies failure, through focus lies success"
"If you show me that you have learned well"
"Then you may draw me in that sketchbook of yours and find serenity."
wolf: I stand before the fearsome statue of a gray wolf
Whose frightening presence would no doubt be a great addition to my sketchbook
I can hear its intimidating, growling voice
"Artist, prepare for one of the greatest challenges of the beginning of your journey"
"If you prevail, I will be glad to join your sketchbook"
"And perhaps devour some of its inhabitants along the way."
rabbit: I stand before the statue of a small, adorable rabbit
Whose fluffiness would no doubt be a great addition to my sketchbook
I can hear its soft chirping voice
"My body is small and weak and cannot forbid you from drawing it"
"As you paint the outline of my frail shape"
"Please remember this moment of calm before the storm."
turtle: I stand before the statue of a sturdy, venerable turtle
Whose resilience would no doubt be a great addition to my sketchbook
I can hear its old, raspy voice
"For countless years, I have seen many of your kind walk in this grove"
"I will remain here for many more years, and I shall remember them all"
spider: I stand before the tiny sculpture of a green spider
Interested by this peculiar piece of artwork
I decide to bring it along on my journey
And paint the outline of this odd creature
In the corner of the first page of my sketchbook.
crow: I stand before the statue of a somber, coal-colored crow
Whose gloominess would no doubt be a great addition to my sketchbook
I can hear its cackling, monotonous voice
"No matter how far you get and what beautiful paintings you come up with"
"Death will come to you, and reduce your body to ash"
"Then perhaps your achievements may live on."
frog: I stand before the statue of a minuscule, wise frog
Whose prudence would no doubt be a great addition to my sketchbook
I can hear its humble, polite voice
"You have come far from your home to learn from us"
"If there is only one lesson to remember"
"It is that not all your work is perfect, and that there is no shame in losing some of it."
acolyte: [1;34;40m "I can see that the notion of rest is alien to you"
"For you, every situation is yet another painting waiting to be created, is it not?"
"My apologies, dear Artist, but a sketch of me is not granted"
I open my sketchbook at its first page, as the Acolyte takes on her battle stance.
master1: [1;34;40m"Each statue I have carved possesses a soul of its own."
"However, I am, and will always will be their Master"
"To begin your final test, let us see if you have memorized their lessons."
master2: [1;34;40m"This next battle should be much easier, now that you have acquainted yourself with my fighting style."
"However, make sure to keep painting to the best of your ability!"
"I like to grant a special reward to disciples who truly manage to exceed my expectations."
master3: [1;34;40m"It is time. Show me the true colors of your power!"
"I wish to see every work of art you have crafted in my grove."
"Even the worst Flaws can be turned into something beautiful by the most proficient students!"
